Sir,

Mr Lawrence Peltier Teacher at Batchewana Bay has written me that he has not as yet received his June Quarter Salary. I forwarded his returns at the same time as the other Teachers. In case of it being mislaid I enclose the Copy from this Office. Kindly let me know what is the cause of the delay, he is in need of his money. Kindly send it to him at MANITOWANING, Ont.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

J. D. McLean Esq.,
Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa,

CANADA
Ottawa, August 5, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, in which you state that Mr. Lawrence Peltier, teacher of the Batchawana Indian Day School, has not yet received his cheque for the June quarter.

I beg to say that cheque No. 2767 for $157.50 was sent to Mr. Peltier at Batchawana Bay P. O., on July 8th, last. He should make enquiries at that post-office and if unable to locate the cheque you should advise the Department.

Your obedient servant

J. E. McLEAN

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
ONT.

Ottawa, August 17, 1923.

Madam,-

In reply to your letter of the 14th instant, I beg to say that the cheque for your salary as teacher of the Batchawana Indian day school for the quarter ending June 30th, last, was sent you at Batchawana Bay Post Office on July 5th, last.

As this letter has not been returned to the Department it is presumed that it is being held at the post office at Batchawana Bay, and you should request the postmaster at that point to forward the letter to you.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Pembroke,
Ont.

Ottawa, May 16th, 1924.

Sir:

When Miss Isabelle Peltier was transferred from the Wikwemikong Indian Day School to the Batchewana Indian Day School it was intended to allow her salary at the latter school at the rate of $650 per year. Through an oversight she has been paid at the rate of $700 per year since September 1st, last. She has, therefore, been overpaid an amount of $50, which will be deducted from her June quarter salary.

Please inform Miss Peltier accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Ottawa, October 29, 1924.

Sir,

The Department has not yet received the return from the Batchawana Indian Day School for the quarter ending September 30th.

Please request the teacher to, at once, prepare the usual quarterly return, showing the attendance, days taught, etc., during the month of September. On this return the exact date on which Miss Therese began duties at this school should be stated, as it would appear from the correspondence on file in the Department, that she did not commence duties until a date subsequent to September 10th, and, of course, the Department can only allow salary from the date on which she commenced teaching to September 30th. The return should be forwarded to the Department at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
ONT.

CANADA
Ottawa, May 19th, 1925.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that it has been decided to dispense with the services of Miss Hazel Thero, teacher of the Batchewana Indian Day School, at the end of the present school year, viz: June 30th, next. You will, therefore, be good enough to notify her that her services will not be required after that date. You should see that she prepares and hands to you her quarterly return for the current quarter showing attendance, days taught, etc., and you should submit the same to the Department in order that payment of salary due her can be made.

It will be necessary to obtain the services of another teacher when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, and I should be pleased if you would endeavour to secure a suitable person for the position. The name, qualifications and experience of any applicant received by you should be forwarded for the consideration of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

CANADA
Ottawa, August 5th, 1925.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that Miss Eva M. Robicheau has accepted the position as teacher of the Batchewana Indian Day School for the next school year, to begin duties September 1st. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $80 per month for the ten teaching months in the year.

I have to request that you will give Miss Robicheau every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school. I have requested her to call upon you when proceeding to take up duties, and you can give her any information she requires regarding the work. We hope that she will meet with every success at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

CANADA
Ottawa, July 12th, 1926.

Sir,-

On the June quarter return of the Batchawana Day School, it is noted that the teacher closed the school for summer holidays on June 10th. She states that she taught during the Christmas, Easter and all other holidays during the year.

It is expected that teachers of Indian Day Schools should keep the school open until June 30th, each year and that they should close the school on the regular holidays at such times as they occur.

Please let me have your views on the above matter, in order that there may be a definite understanding, for the next school year, with the teacher of the Batchawana School.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

A.D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Ottawa, September 22nd, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to official letter of July 12th, last, relative to teaching during the regular holiday periods at the Batchewana Indian Day School. Mr. Inspector Bennett has drawn this matter to the attention of the Department in connection with the Goulais Bay Indian Day School.

It is not considered in the best interests of the children for the teachers to keep these schools open during the Christmas and Easter holiday periods in order that they can close early in June. The schools should be closed for the regular holiday periods and kept open until the end of June next. You will be good enough to advise the teachers at these schools accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Sir,

I beg to enclose a petition from the Batchewana Band of Indians residing at Batchewana Bay in reference to a school as you will see there are thirty-six (36) children between the ages of five and fourteen years who have never had a school. The children are bright and very intelligent, and it would be conferred a great favor on them if they could be sent to school. If a school was built on the shore near Batchewana Dock it would be accessible on all sides.

I would recommend that a school be given these people. Kindly let me know what you think of the proposition.

And much obliged,

Your obedient servant,

3. The Indians at Batchewana submitted a petition signed by the majority of the Indians residing there asking that a school house be erected there and a teacher supplied as there are over forty Indian children at that place which is twenty-five miles from Goulais Bay where there is a school. I would strongly recommend that their petition be granted. I saw many of the children and they are bright and intelligent, and I felt sorry to think that they had no school. As there are a couple of white families at Batchewana, I have no doubt a teacher would get board and lodging with one of them. (Mr. Miller is the name of one of the white men and Jewell the name of the other.) (Goulais Bay)

Your obedient servant,
J. W. Shore,
Ottawa, 30th July, 1912.
Ottawa, August 7, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo enclosing a petition from the Indians of Batchewana for the establishment of a school.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the number of children of school age, the Department is disposed to look favourably upon this request and I have to ask you to make inquiries and advise whether there is any building available which could be used for school purposes. As you are aware this is not a reserve and it is not the policy of the Department to erect buildings outside reserves, but an exception might be made in this case owing to the fact that these Indians have been so long located there, provided a proper title could be secured to the property. Mr. Shore informs the Department that there is a place where a teacher could find lodging accommodation and, if there is any building available, the Department is prepared to pay a rental for it, provide the salary of a teacher and assume the other expenses incidental to the management of the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, September 3, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo in further reference to the establishment of a school at Batchewana.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is prepared to rent the building to which you refer, provided the services of a teacher are available, and will pay for it at the rate of $30.00 per annum. It is expected, however, that the money that will have to be expended on repairs will go towards paying the first year's rent, if at all possible. In any event the rent should be somewhat reduced to pay for these remains, which, you state, will cost about $30.00.

A lease should be drawn up and signed by the owner. I have to ask you to be good enough to state before having these repairs made whether you know of anyone who would be willing to undertake the work at this school. In the meantime the Department is communicating with a young lady in Sudbury and will let you know as soon as it hears from her.

Your obedient servant,

Would you please tell me by return of mail if you did buy Mr. Chris Thompson house and if you are going to fix it up for a school house and teacher's residence. Indian Agent Dye Hatt promised he was going to have it ready for me. The Indians are all living down near the dock about 2½ miles from here where the Church is, and when I arrived here I had no place to stay only for Mrs. Willard kindness I would have been stuck for a place to sleep. For the present time I am using Father Parcher's House near the Church and am all alone up here my nearest neighbors are about 1½ miles away & can't get settled and don't know where to get the wood piled, as we must have wood this year, Mr. Mr. Hatt did.
not come to his office in the Soo while I was there I waited all day for him at his office door and he does not write to me to explain matters so I thought the quickest way was to write to you. That building is much warmer than the one we are teaching in now but it will need whitewashing, new windows, one inside door and I was thinking a partition & wallboard for my bed Room would be cheaper than getting lumber and would be quicker put up and would be finished and look nicer and the ceiling can be of wallboard also. I am only suggesting this; you don't need to have wallboard if you don't want it but it will come cheaper and be a better job. If you answer soon I can let you know what you need and how high the room is also the length so you will know how many pieces of wall board to send or lumber. There are 3 families living near the church just now they are living near the Dock so I am all alone.
Here, I hope they soon come up. There are just 2 children from the 3 families will attend school. The rest are living down near the building I hear you bought. I hope I soon know what you are doing so I can get settled for the winter just now. I have to be brave and it is hard. Shall I give you a hint as to what I will do if you get the place fixed? I close hoping you will soon write to me.

Yours Faithfully,
Isabelle Peltier

Sir—

In reference to the Batchewana School, I have now a chance to buy the house that the Inspector recommended some time ago. The owner Chris Thompson died a couple of months ago and his executor offered me the house for $50.00; there is no land going with the House but we could let it remain where it is and use it, it is right in the centre of the Village.

What we paid last winter for hauling the children to school would fix up the house, all we require is a couple of thousand feet of Lumber and some 2 or 3 barrels of Lime.

It is a Log House and at any time we could move it to the land owned by the Dept., for School.

I met the Inspector today at the Catholic School at Garden River and he urged me to try and buy, as it is so handy for the Pupils, Awaiting your early instructions.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, in which you recommend that the house owned by the late Chris Thompson be purchased for the sum of $50, to be used for school purposes on the Batchewana Reserve. In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of this house for the amount mentioned, viz $50, and will pay this sum upon receipt of properly certified vouchers from you covering the cost.

You may arrange for the purchase of 2000' of lumber and 3 barrels of lime. You may also arrange to have the necessary alterations made to the building to provide classroom accommodation and living quarters for the teacher. You should consult the teacher as to the alterations that will be required to provide living quarters for her. It may be necessary to erect certain partitions to provide a bedroom. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred in fitting up the building. When the repairs have been completed and the building is in proper condition for school purposes, you should arrange for the transfer of all school equipment and furniture from the building in which the school is at present held.

It is considered that this building is more centrally located, and, it is felt that, when it is fitted up for classroom purposes, it will provide for the educational requirements on this Reserve for sometime to come.

The purchase of the building, repairs and alterations required should receive your prompt attention.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON BATCHAWANA SCHOOL.

September 7th & 8th, 1924.

1. Asbestos needed on roof around chimney

2. The key was left with Frank Lapointe, fisherman, so that he could, after or during rain storm, empty a pail that was placed under the pipes in the chimney, as the flashing in the roof was so poorly fixed around the chimney that rain usually poured in. This needs fixing.

3. Classroom is too dark. A window 4 x 3 in the gable end will help. Windows are very small.

4. There is no woodshed. Wood is kept in classroom around walls. A lean-to is all that is needed.

5. The only light into the kitchen is from the top half of the door but this is boarded up as window was broken. It needs fixing. 2½ x 2½.

J. M. Bennett,
Insp.
Ottawa, September 15th, 1924.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Batchewana Indian Day School, states that the flashing on the roof around the chimney is so poorly fixed that the rain comes through into the building. He recommends that the roof around the chimney be repaired with asbestos or other suitable material. He also states that the classroom is too dark and recommends that a window 4'x3' be placed in the gable end of the building. He further states that there is no woodshed at this school and that the wood is kept in the classroom around the walls, and that the only light in the kitchen is from the top half of the door, which is boarded up as the glass is broken.

I have to request that you will make immediate arrangements to have the roof of the building around the chimney repaired and placed in good condition. You should also arrange to have a window placed in the gable end of the classroom and the door into the kitchen repaired. Regarding the providing of a woodshed, it is considered that a lean-to to the building is all that is required. You may arrange to have an inexpensive lean-to put up to provide storage facilities for the wood. You should engage the services of a competent man to carry out these repairs and put up the woodshed. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred. You should purchase any materials required.

The Department expects you to have the above work completed at an early date, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of any material supplied and for the labour engaged.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 1, 1925:

Sir,

The Separate School Inspector in a report on his recent inspection of the Matchewan Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the school building and the urgent need of repairs. He states that the following work should be done in order to place this building in good condition:

(1) A brick chimney should be built in order to prevent fire. It should be built in the centre of the building to serve both stoves. The inspector states that this building caught fire last fall on account of the defective chimney.

(2) About fifteen lengths of stove pipe should be supplied as soon as the new chimney is completed.

(3) All floors require two coats of ground colour and one coat of oak stain. In their present condition they are very hard to keep clean.

(4) Where the roof sits on the walls there is urgent need for plastering and filling up holes to keep out the cold. At present even the rain comes in under the eaves.

(5) The inside partitions require to be painted.

As most of this work appears necessary and could be carried out without large expense, I have to request that you will arrange to have the repairs mentioned above completed during the coming summer holidays. You should purchase any material required and have it forwarded to Matchewan and you should arrange for the labour in doing the work. The Department will expect that you will attend to this matter and have this building placed in a comfortable condition before the cold weather commences next fall. The Department will rely on you to see that while a satisfactory job is completed, no unnecessary expense is incurred. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of any material supplied and for the labour employed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. G. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
ONT.

Sir;

In reply to your letter of June 1st No 13-1-5 in reference to Batchewana School, I beg to say that the repairs required is of such a nature that it requires a mechanic to do it and it will be expensive to send a man from here. In addition to the repairs mentioned in your letter we require a woodshed to hold at least 16 cords of wood as our wood is piled outside and we have no protection from theft or fire.

If this was added I might get a man to go and take a contract of the whole repairs, as it is just now I cannot get any person here to go up as transportation is such that a person has to engage a Launch to get out of Batchewana. Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, requesting that authority be granted to have certain repairs made to the school building at Batchewana.

In this connection I would point out that you have not stated the approximate cost of having the painting, whitewashing, plastering, etc., carried out. The Department will, however, approve of your making the necessary arrangements while you are at Batchewana to have the work which you consider to be absolutely necessary at this school carried out. You should see that no unnecessary expense is incurred. You should arrange for the purchase of any materials required and for the labour in having the work done. You should also see that the work which you arrange to have done is satisfactorily completed.

After the work is finished to your satisfaction, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Department will leave the matter of the painting, etc., in your hands to have the work completed at the least possible expense.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Complying with your request in letter No 13-1-5 June 10th last, to look over the school property in Batchawana while up paying the Indians their Treaty money. I beg to state that I looked over the school and find it requires whitewashing, floors painted, also a number of broken glass replaced in windows. I engaged Mrs Miller the Storekeeper, who is a very capable woman, to supervise the work and she will hire Indians to do it. I am shipping material required for the job. This will be by far the cheapest way to do the work as it would cost too much to send men from here.

I also engaged Joe Tom Sayer to cut 15 double cords of hard-wood at $8.00 per cord and 2 cords soft-wood for kindling at $8.00 per cord.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Ottawa, June 9, 1928.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Batchewana Indian Day School, states that the roof of the school building leaks badly and recommends that it be replaced by a new one. He also states that the interior walls and floors require painting.

I have to request that you will furnish a report on the repairs required to this building, stating the cost of re-shingling the roof and any other repairs required, including material and labour, also the cost of painting the interior walls and floors. This matter should receive your early attention in order that if it is decided to have any work carried out it can be performed during the coming summer holidays. If you recommend that any repairs be carried out, you should state whether the work could be done by day labour, under the charge of a competent foreman, you to arrange for the purchase and delivery of all material required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. H. Sima, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 26, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, giving an estimate of the material and labour in reshingling the roof of the Batchawana Indian Day School building.

The old shingles should be removed and heavy tar paper laid on the roof, also some of the roofing boards removed and the new shingles laid on. Flashing should be placed around the chimneys on the roof and the walls of the building, inside and outside, whitewashed; the floor in the classroom, painted, and the necessary quantity of oil cloth purchased for the kitchen and bedroom floors, also oil cloth for the kitchen table. You should purchase the shingles and other material required and have same forwarded to Batchawana and you should arrange for the labour in having the shingling and other repairs carried out.

We note that you estimate the cost of the material to be approximately $147, and the labour, $40. If possible, please keep the cost within these amounts. You should see that a satisfactory job is performed and that a good grade of shingles is used. After the work is completed, please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and for the labour. Please have this work carried out when the school is closed for the summer holidays.

Dear Sir:

When making a sanitary survey of the schools in my district I found that your Indian school at Batchewana was badly in need of a water supply close to the school. The children are compelled to carry water from the shore of Lake Superior some 400 feet away and it would be impossible for them to secure water when the drift ice came in in the early Fall. I would suggest that a driven well be located on the school property a convenient distance from the school. The formation of the soil at this point, I believe, would be ideal for a driven well, and if successful there would be no possible chance of the water becoming contaminated.

I also made an inspection of your Indian School at Garden River and found that the toilet accommodation was not sufficient for the number of pupils.

I found on inspection of the Batchewana and Garden River schools that they were kept exceptionally clean and well looked after by those in charge.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, in which you seek authority to purchase certain supplies for the repairs at the Batchawana Indian Day School.

I may state that, for some reason that I cannot explain, your letter of July 20 was not brought to my attention until August 25, and I can only express regret at the failure of the Department to reach a decision in respect to this matter until now. Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,

Dear Sir:

On July 20th I forwarded a requisition for supplies required for the Batchewana Indian Day School.

In this requisition, I stated that a cook stove was needed, the approximate cost of which would be $30.00. I am unable to say just where I obtained this estimate of $30.00 but upon making inquiries at local stores in the Sault, I find that the cheapest stove that I can buy to fill the bill, will cost $57.00.

As the Batchewana School is badly in need of a new cook stove, I would like to be given authority to purchase one at the above mentioned cost. I might also add that this stove must be a fair sized one, as it is not only used as a cook stove but to heat the teacher's quarters at the school.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The toilets at the Batchewana Indian Day School are not fit to be used any longer. They have been built of old lumber and are now falling apart, new ones should be built.

The approximate cost of two toilets would be $85.00, labour $30.00, material $50.00, transportation $5.00.

Kindly advise me if it will be in order to proceed with the above work this summer.

RPG/LMY

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

R.A. Hoey,

I do not think that I can add much to my report of last June.

As is the case at West Bay, the Indians at Batchawana are tired of seeing Miss Robicheau around. Some years ago two or three Indians approached me in regard to the securing of another teacher. General comment:

A splendid little school.

It being difficult to arrange taxi service to these outlying schools in these days of gasoline and rubber shortage, Mr. Agent Lawrence, who was planning to visit the Goulais Bay and Batchawana reserves, kindly arranged his time-table to allow me to accompany him.

I had the children count for him, and think he was surprized at the speed and accuracy of even the youngest of the children. At one time the children of this school were counting on their fingers, and the change since made shows what can be done if the teacher really wants to.

As I visit this school year after year I marvel more and more how Miss Robicheau can so well maintain her interest and efficiency, remembering that she has now been teaching in this out-of-the-way school for some nineteen years or so.

General comment:

I think that good work is being done at this little school. I should like to see the work in the work book; done a little more neatly, and Miss Robicheau is keeping this in mind when correcting the books. Apart from this, however, I am more than satisfied with the work being done. In counting, for example, the children are more proficient than in most of the Provincial schools visited by me.

In view of War Conditions, it is difficult to arrange for transportation to this school, which is approximately sixty miles from the Sault, and can be reached only by car. I called down to see Mr. Agar Lawrence in case he might be visiting this reserve during my stay at the Sault. He was kind enough to so arrange his visiting of his reserves as to visit Batchawana and Goulais Bay on November 24th, and to take me with him. I should like to record my obligation to Mr. Lawrence for this assistance, as otherwise it might have been impossible for me to visit these two schools during the school year 1943/44. It will most likely be pretty bad driving when I am next in this locality, just before Easter.

I should like to refer to my report dated May 17, 1944, on the Rabbit Island Indian Day School. In that report I made certain remarks about Miss Robicheau, and suggested that she might be offered the Rabbit Island School was flattered by the way in which the recommendations made in that report were so cordially accepted. As it turned out, however, Miss Robicheau's mother was ill, and it was not known when Miss Robicheau might have to go home. (As a matter of fact her mother died this spring). For this reason Miss Robicheau felt unable to take the Rabbit Island School for fear of being shown in at some inconvenient time.

I now venture to recommend that she be offered the Serpent River School at Cutler. I spoke to her when I was at Batchawana, and she agreed that she would like the school. Sir,

I beg to report that I got the Batchewana Bay School started on Tuesday last with 17 pupils the first morning. I had a great deal of difficulty in getting a Boarding place for the Teacher. I thought at one time I would have to take her back, at last I got a man named Joe Robineon a member of the Michipicot Band to take her providing I would furnish him with Lumber to partition off a bedroom, also furnish her own bedding. I hesitated about buying the necessary lumber and bedding but I considered that under the circumstances the Department would overlook my doing so without authority, so I purchased Lumber to the amount of $7.00. I bought her pair of Grey Blankets (all I could get) I also got her some Bedding and Towels, and an Alarm Clock, for which I will forward Bills as soon as received. I don't worry if you think you spent too much on this school house and residence. I wish some of the Authorities would see the place it is not a palace by any means. I was real happy in this little home and all the food is taken off it when I get letters from the Indian Agent saying you will kick at the cost of the place. I know the men were slow but Indians are always that way unless you stand and watch them. I had to be at school teaching and that is a mile from...
here or more I had to trust them to keep their time and as to getting articles we needed to complete the building such as Tar Paper, Stove Flaps, hinges, White Wash Brushes, Brooms, oilcloth I did need it and if I had waited to write to Mr. Habb I would not have been here yet our mail is sometimes ten days on the way we get mail but once a week.

Mr. Mr. Habb did not send me any table or chairs, so I got the men to make two tables for me in the kitchen out of rough Lumber and thought you would not mind if I got a few yards oilcloth to cover tables and Wash stand
I did my best to get it done cheap but things are not so cheap up here. I had to borrow chairs. I'm real sorry you are displeased but I am real comfortable and the children are happy here we can now do as we like as this is not a church. We are going to have a Xmas Tree and Concert on Dec. 22nd '23. It is the first the Indians ever had here so it's a great event ha' ha'.

Oh & forgot to say the men also built 3 closets and banked the house too. It was a lot of work to fix up the
old place. Write and let me know just how you feel about it, Mr. Dabb should have come up himself I think.

But I'll say once more this is very much nicer now a teacher will be so much happier in this as it is clean and comfortable.

Yours Truly,

Miss Isabelle Peltier
Batchewana Bay
Ont.
Ottawa, Dec. 22, 1923.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, regarding the expenditure incurred in fitting up and furnishing teacher's living quarters at the Batchawana Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say the Department is pleased to learn that satisfactory arrangements are now completed for the accommodation of the teacher. Accounts for the supplies, forwarded by Mr. Agent McNabb, have been received and paid. If you have any further accounts for work done by Indian labour, you should forward proper vouchers and receipts to Mr. McNabb, who will certify and transmit them to the Department for payment. While the costs of furnishing the teacher's living quarters and the repairs were higher than anticipated, the Department has raised no question regarding the same.

We note that you are arranging for a concert and Christmas tree for the pupils. We hope that you will meet with every success in your work as teacher of this school and that, as a result of the supplies forwarded and the work done, you will be comfortable during the coming winter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a communication from W. F. Brown, Batchewana Bay, Ont., in which he states that he is desirous of obtaining two acres of land on which to erect a house. In 1914 the Department purchased approximately two acres of land situated in Section 19 of the Township of Fisher for the purpose of building a school and teacher's residence. The Department understands that the present school was built on this land. Sir,

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo No. 13-1-19 with reference to a communication from W.F. Brown of Batchewana Bay asking for information regarding two acres of land in the Township of Fisher owned by the Indian Department.

In reply I may say that this land is situated one half mile from the present school, is not on any reserve, and is a part of the S.E.1/4 of Section 19 Township of Fisher.

Mr. Brown carries on a small store at Batchewana with his mother Mrs. S. Miller, is a white man, and I believe it is his intention to purchase this land for summer cottage sites. I am sure this is the two acres which the Department purchased in 1914 for a school site, but it was situated so far away from the Indian homes that the school was never built on it.

Mr. Brown offers $100.00 for the two acres which I think is a fair offer. However, I am of the opinion that in a year or two it may be worth much more, as this is a very desirable site for summer homes.

I have the honor to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 500 days in each year.

Schools shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 22nd.

The winter term will commence on January 3rd, and end on June 30th each year.

The following holidays will be allowed during the year:—All Statutory, Labour Day, all Bank Holiday Mondays, Christmas, Easter Monday, the remainder of the week following Easter Monday, King's Birthday, Good Friday, Easter Monday, the remainder of the week following Easter Monday.

In addition to the above, the Reserve Day Schools will be allowed at holidays a limited number of half days of observation, not to exceed two days in any one week, which will be accounted as working days and for which payment of salary will be allowed.

Where in the interest of the school work, it becomes necessary to declare the school closed during the regular times of the year, but no change is to be made without the express approval of the Department.

Plan: To 4 yrs., with a recess during each session of not less than 15 and not more than 30 minutes.

Vacation in this Regulation without Department approval.

Salaries of teachers will be paid on a basis of ten (10) teaching weeks in each school year.

Salaries will be paid at the end of each quarter, upon receipt of quarterly returns, unless otherwise specified in the regulations for the quarter. If school is regularly taught—three months' salary will be paid at the end of the quarter.

Summer holidays are not taken into account in pursuance of treaty obligations. Each school shall begin and end on the dates mentioned above, until the yearly regulations of the Department for the period following the holiday period.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

All questions relating to the day school should be referred to the local Indian Agent.

My daughter Annie McDayall has been teaching at the Bear Creek Day School on the Caradoc Indian Reserve, for a number of years, and has been teacher there for ten months of the present year. When she received her salary cheque for the quarter ending the 30th of September, she found that the Department had retained sixty dollars allowing her no salary during the summer holidays. I beg to say that during the holidays she has several times taken a horse and buggy and visited all the homes of her pupils instructing in taking care of their gardens, grains, chickens, sewing &c. The seed and eggs for the same were furnished to them by the Department of Agriculture and I am informed that her pupils won more prizes at their school fair than the other four schools combined for a reference on this matter will Mr. Hiram Gordon, District Representative of the Department of Agriculture. Would you kindly look into this matter, as we believe you will be good enough to send her the amount retained or at least $5 of it which would be a proportionate share of the teaching months.

I am very truly yours,

A. S. McDayall
Ottawa, November 22, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant with reference to the amount of salary paid your daughter, Miss Annie McDougall, for the period which she taught the Bear Creek Day School during the months of September and October, last.

In reply I beg to say that your daughter resigned from the position of teacher to take effect on the 30th of September, last, but she remained and taught during the month of October until her successor was appointed. During the month of September she taught twenty days and in October twenty-one days. In paying salaries the Department does not take holidays into account; each teacher is required to teach two hundred days in the school year in order to draw the full yearly salary. Your daughter's salary was at the rate of $400.00 per annum and for the September quarter she was paid 20/200 of that amount, or $40.00, and for the month of October she was paid 21/200 of the yearly salary, amounting to $42.00. Her successor, Miss McGugan, began her duties on the first of the present month and, as there is only $400.00 per year provided for salary for the teacher at this school, the balance will be required to pay Miss McGugan for her services, if she remains and teaches till the 30th of June, next, the end of the school year. This system of payment is the same as

A. S. McDougall, Esq.,
Melbourne, Ont.

To the Deputy Dept. General
of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Hon. Sir,

I have received a check for $40.00
from Mr. Henry James, Indian Agent,
purporting to be the amount due me for
services as teacher of Bear Creek School,
Caradoc Indian Reservation, and it appears
you have made no allowance for Midsummer
Holidays, which I think I am entitled to,
as I spent much time during the holidays
preparing for the School Fair. I regret to say I was
compelled to leave school owing to poor
health, but I would be pleased to take
up the work at a later date, providing
of course, if the Department so desires.
If I am not entitled to the whole amount,
surely I should receive the proportion
which the total days taught bears to the
whole teaching days in the year.

As I have given you good service for several years, which all official reports will testify I trust you will look this matter up and remit to me the furthest amount due me.

I have the honor to be Sir,

your obedient servant,

Annie McDougall.
Sir,

I herewith enclose a letter which I have received from Miss Annie McDougall, former teacher of Bear Creek Indian School. This letter from her will speak for itself.

In regard to the above I might say Miss McDougall has always given the best satisfaction in this school and as she taught this school until Nov 1st 1916, I should think she should be entitled to pay for the midsummer holiday period.

Your obedient servant

J.Jones

The Sec.
Dept Ind. Affairs
Ottawa Ont.
Ottawa, December 9, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in reference to the amount of salary paid Miss Annie McDougall, late teacher of the Bear Creek School, for the period which she taught during the months of September and October, last, and enclosing a communication which you received from her in reference to this matter.

In reply I beg to say that the Department was in receipt of a communication from A. S. McDougall of the same date as the letter which you enclose and he was informed fully as the method adopted by the Department in the payment of salaries of teachers of day schools for broken periods. Miss McDougall has received the full amount due her for her services to October 31st, the date on which she finally gave up her duties as teacher of this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Janes, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Delaware, Ont.

Ottawa, December 12th, 1924.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing applications for the positions as teachers of the Bear Creek and River Settlement Indian Day Schools.

In reply I beg to say that these applications are considered to be satisfactory and the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Mattie Dowding as teacher of the Bear Creek Indian Day School and of the appointment of Miss Eliza Haldorff as teacher of the River Settlement Indian Day School, both to begin duties when the schools reopen after the Christmas holidays. The salary allowed to each will be at the rate of $300 per year, supplemented by the bonus provided by law. Payment of both salary and bonus is based on ten teaching months in the year. It is noted that both these teachers have second class certificates. Please inform these two ladies of their appointments and arrange with them to take up duties at the beginning of the new year. We note that good living accommodation can be had for both within a very short distance of the schools. It is hoped that they will both meet with every success in their work, and I should be pleased if you could give them every assistance you can upon their taking up duties.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Secretary.

Thos. McGookin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, informing the Department that Miss Margaret Baird, teacher of the Bear Creek Indian Day School, had, on account of the death of her brother, been called home, and that she will be unable to take up her teaching duties until after the Easter holidays. In this connection I have to confirm the following telegram to you of today's date:

"Engage substitute Bear Creek School. Writing."

It is noted that the Public School Inspector can obtain the services of a substitute teacher to take charge of this school during the absence of Miss Baird and that the teacher he can obtain has a second class certificate. The Department will allow the substitute a salary at the rate of $35 per teaching month. We cannot, however, allow Miss Baird any salary for the period she is absent from duty. When forwarding the return for the current quarter the date upon which Miss Baird went on leave and also the dates between which the substitute teacher was employed should be stated thereon. Please inform the Department of the name of the substitute engaged during the absence of Miss Baird.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Ottawa, July 31, 1930.

Sir:

I have your 1-5-1 of the 25th instant, announcing the resignation of the teacher of the Bear Creek Indian Day School. Miss Baird's resignation is accepted. The Department has decided to fill this post from the applications on file. I have to state that Miss Wilma Gardner, who holds an Interim Second Class Certificate, is appointed, at a salary of $900 for the 10 teaching months. Miss Gardner is known to officers of the Department and we look for a career of much usefulness in her case. She has had no experience but will attack her problems in the right spirit and I am hopeful that you will find her quite successful.

I have informed Miss Gardner that boarding facilities can be found at Middlemiss, which is but little more than a mile distant. She intends to visit your office and the school before September first. When she presents herself, you might give her any assistance you can in the matter of securing a boarding house.

I should be grateful if you would speak to both the truant officer and the janitor at this school and urge them to give the new teacher every assistance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, 24th March, 1896.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to report that a resolution has been passed by the council of the Gidwem Band of the Thames in favour of an expenditure not to exceed $400, being made from their capital—which amounts to $75,783.54—on the erection of a school-house to replace the old one now in use on the Caradoc Reserve.

The Agent for the Band states that the present building has become unfit for use, and approves of the resolution.

As the new building would be in the nature of a permanent improvement and properly represent capital, the undersigned would respectfully recommend that authority be given, under Section 139 of the Indian Act, for charging the construction of the same, at a cost not exceeding $400, to the capital at the credit of the above named band.

[Signature]

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

The Minister recommends, as the Agent for the Band states that the present building has become unfit for use, and approves of the resolution, and as the new building would be in the nature of a permanent improvement and properly represent capital, that authority be given under Section 139 of the Indian Act for charging the construction of the same, at a cost not exceeding $400.00, to the capital at the credit of the above named band.

The Committee submit the same for Your Excellency's approval.

Indian Office
Ottawa Sept 22, 1906.

Sir:

The foundation under the Bear Creek School House is in a ruined condition; cement enough having not been used to make a good job, at present it is crumbling away. I herewith enclose a Resolution from the Council of the Chippewas of the Thames, asking that a concrete foundation be put under Bear Creek School House. The cost of the same not to exceed Twenty Dollars ($20.00) to be paid out of the funds of the Band.

I recommend the Resolution.

[Signature]
S. Macdonald
Indian Agent

Sec. Dept.
Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Ottawa, September 27, 1906.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd inst., inclosing a resolution passed by the council of the Chippewas of the Thames providing for the expenditure of the sum of not exceeding $75 from the funds of the band for the purpose of placing a concrete foundation under the Bear Creek school-house.

In reply I beg to say that this resolution is approved and the work may be undertaken at once provided it is placed in competent hands under your direction.

Your obedient Servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Secretary.

S. Sutherland, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Delaware, Ont.

JUNE 5, 1924.

The main building needs a coat of paint very badly.

The closets are not sanitary. There is enough lumber in them to make two good and suitable closets. The present ones are anything but suitable. They are placed in very low situations and there is no arrangement for cleaning them. The closets should be built on cement foundations.

Ottawa, July 21, 1924.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Bear Creek Indian Day School, states that the closets are in a very unsanitary condition and are anything but suitable. They are placed in very low situations and there is no arrangement for cleaning them.

If the cost of cleaning these closets, since the Inspector visited the school, was not included in the account which you submitted on the 24th ultimo for putting down cement walks and gravel paths and cleaning out closets, you should see that they are thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good sanitary condition.

The Inspector further states that the school yard ground is very uneven and recommends that it be ploughed, harrowed level and re-seeded. I shall be pleased to have your report regarding this matter, stating the cost of having the required levelling carried out.

It is presumed that you have arranged for the painting of the school building, as authorized in official letter of the 20th ultimo. It is hoped that this work will be completed before the school re-opens after the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reply to your letter No.7-5-5, of the 21st inst., regarding Bear Creek day school.

I beg to say that the closets have been cleaned out and the ground around them has been gravelled and are in a clean sanitary condition. The cost of this work was included in voucher submitted on the 24th ultimo.

Regarding the school yard, which the inspectors recommended should be ploughed and re-seeded. This ground is clay and if ploughed would take a long time before it could be used as a play-ground, there were several low spots which have been filled in with gravel, making the yard quite level and in good condition.

The work of painting the school building will be commenced in the course of a few days. Angus Albert, who was awarded the contract, only returned to the Reserve yesterday. The work will be completed before school opens for Fall term.

Sir,

I have been talking with the teachers of the Day Schools on this reserve regarding a hot lunch for the pupils during the winter months; they are all agreed that it would be an excellent thing for the pupils. Dr. Woods, however, has suggested that a glass of milk each day at recess would be more beneficial, as the majority of the pupils do not get any milk at home, and as they are predisposed to tuberculosis, the milk would supply what is lacking in their daily food and help to build their resistance.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No.7-5-5 of the 28th ultimo, with reference to the Public School Inspector's report upon the water supply at the Bear Creek Day School.

I beg to say that, in my opinion this school has an excellent water supply, while not on the school grounds, it is obtained from a well about fifty yards from the school building, on the premises of Mr. Daniel Albert. This water is of excellent quality and has been used by the pupils and teacher for many years for drinking purposes.

While visiting the school recently, the water supply was mentioned to the teacher, and she informed me that all the water the pupils could use was available and that several pails of fresh water was used each day.

There is a well on the school premises, but the water is unfit for drinking; the well has been cleaned out and a top installed, but the water is still unfit for use. I am doubtful if the digging of a new well on the grounds would be satisfactory or the expenditure justified, so long as the water can be obtained from the present source. I do not recommend going to the expense of digging another well.

Miss Baird, Miss Comfort and Miss Howe, teachers on the Chippewa section of Caradoc Reserve, have requested that I take up with Dept. the building of car garages at each of their schools. In all three cases, their homes or boarding houses are miles from their school and it is necessary for them to use cars to get there and all day in all kinds of weather their cars must remain outside as there is no building to put them in. I understand a portable garage can be put up for around $100.00 and would ask your consideration of the erection of such a garage at each of the schools of the above-mentioned teachers.
Ottawa, December 14, 1929.

Sir,

Referring to your monthly report of inspection of the Bear Creek, Muncey and Back Settlement Indian Day Schools in which you recommend that garages for the teachers' use be erected at each of these schools, I have to say that the Department will approve of the providing of garage accommodation at the Back Settlement and Muncey Day Schools. If weather conditions permit, you may arrange for the erection of a garage of the portable type at each of these schools. You should see that the site selected in each case does not interfere with the playground accommodation or the general appearance of the school building. We note you estimate the cost of the erection of a portable garage to be approximately $100, but, if possible, to do so, they should be furnished at each school at less cost. The Department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in the providing of suitable garage facilities for the teachers at both these schools. After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately.

Relative to the erection of a garage at the Bear Creek School, the Department does not consider that this is necessary at the present time. We understand that the teacher resides in the village of Middlesex, which is only a mile distant from the school, and that a car is not necessary to get to and from her school in any condition of weather.

The Department will expect to hear from you as soon as the two garages authorized above have been completed, with full particulars as to the type, cost, etc.

Sir,

I would beg to inform you of the request of the teacher of Bear Creek Indian Day School of Caradoc Agency that a cupboard for the classroom at this school be supplied, as she complains that she has not the necessary book case or desk, with which to store the material necessary to conduct the classroom and that the public school inspector on his last visit desired that she have an additional cupboard installed.

In view of the fact that there is no ante room at this school, there is no place for her to keep her supplies and I would recommend that a suitable cupboard or book case be built in the classroom and the material and cost of construction should not exceed in the vicinity of $20.00. A few minor repairs are needed to the outer houses and fence at the school and I would wish your authority to have these repairs made.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Ottawa, July 8, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Bear Creek Indian Day School that a cupboard for classroom supplies be provided.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have a suitable cupboard or bookcase built in the classroom, and the cost of same should not exceed your estimate of approximately $20.

After the cupboard has been completed to your satisfaction, you should obtain an account, in duplicate, which you should certify and forward to the Department, when payment will be made.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

There is a well at the Bear Creek school that has not been used for over 15 years due to the fact that the water after being tested was found unfit for use. August 23rd, 1924. Birch Island portion.

Mr. R. J. Lewis,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning.

Sir:

We the undersigned sign and pass a resolution that a school be open for benefit of children of this band.

Signed, Elie McGregor
Stephen Esquimaux
Dave McGregor
Gregor McGregor
John Raibomsai
Sam Keshikgobness
Andrew Raibomsai
Moses Esquimaux
Gus McGregor
Chief William McGregor.
Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a copy of a resolution by the Chief and Principal men of the Whitefish River Band requesting that a school be opened at Birch Island on the unsurrendered portion of the Whitefish River Reserve for the benefit of the children residing there.

With regard to this matter I have the honour to report to the Department that I visited the Birch Island portion of the Whitefish River Reserve and found that there are twelve Indian children of school age residing in the vicinity of a school if one should be opened at Birch Island. The majority of the children are of Roman Catholic parents.

There is an old building at Birch Island which was in use some years ago as an Indian school and church and was conducted under the auspices of the Anglican church authorities. Now it is used as an Anglican church and council hall, but it is not in a fit state by any means to be used as a school now.

As the Band desire that a school be opened, and at the present time there are twelve children of school age along with fifteen children under age residing in the vicinity of Birch Island I would suggest to the Department that a new comfortable class-room and teacher's residence be erected at Birch Island. If a school is opened at this point it will be permanent for years to come as the majority of the Indians of the Whitefish River Band reside at Birch Island and there are a number of young children.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, September 3rd, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing copy of a resolution of the Chief and principal men of the Whitefish River Band requesting that a school be opened at Birch Island on the unsurrendered portion of the Whitefish River Reserve, and stating the number of children of school age and the condition of the building which was formerly used for school purposes.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has no funds available in the appropriation for the present fiscal year for the erection of a building on this Reserve. This request will, however, be noted for next year's estimates, and will receive consideration when the same are being prepared for submission to Parliament. We note that if a school is opened at this point it will be permanent for a number of years, as the majority of the Indians reside at Birch Island, and there will be a sufficient number of Indian children to attend. You may inform the Indians interested that the question of erecting a building and re-opening a school at Birch Island will receive consideration as stated above.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.
Whitefish River Reserve,
at Birch Island,

Sir;—

I have the honour to report that during the current school quarter Miss Annie L. Douglas was absent, and the Birch Island School was closed for five weeks, as she was forced to undergo an operation for appendicitis.

When I paid the school a visit recently she advised me that it was her intention to teach during the midsummer holidays to make up for lost time through sickness, and I advised her that she might teach during Christmas and Easter holidays for to make up some of the lost time, but it would not be advisable to teach during the summer holidays, as during that season of the year the weather is warm, and the Indians would be away picking berries, therefore, the attendance would be small.

During the time Miss Douglas lost at school the teacher's quarters were not any too desirable, but as the new school building was under construction and was ready for occupation upon her return after the operation both she and the pupils are now comfortable, which they were not while conducting school in the church building.

I would most respectfully recommend that Miss Douglas be paid her salary for the time lost through sickness and it may be that she will be able to make up a portion of the time lost before the midsummer holidays set in, but I would not recommend that school be conducted during the midsummer holidays.

Dear Sir,

I wish you a very Christmas and a happy New Year, and I thank you heartily for all that you have done for the welfare of the native missions and schools.

Miss Mary Clarke, teaching at Birch Island, has fulfilled her duties with satisfaction and punctuality, and certainly she deserves credit for having succeeded with so great energy and success, and for being glad to come back, first Tuesday, after the Christmas holidays. The late Mr. Ferrier made certainly a good choice.

Till the end of December Miss Clarke used to go to Kit-tena sometime, for shopping on the Saturday before noon train, and come back in the ferry-boat next day; on Sunday afternoon. But, this is not more possible. The ferry-boat is back up till spring, and the next train from L.C. east to Birch is due at Birch only on Monday 3 p.m., so, she will have to go shopping at Kapunda, east to Birch Island. The train leaves for Kapunda at 3 p.m., at Birch, and the next train could be Monday a.m. 11 o'clock, to come back to Birch. There is no train on Sunday—

So, then writing you to grant Miss Clarke permission to come back on Sunday morning, at 11 o'clock, from Kapunda, after having taught Saturday morning.
to make up for Monday before noon—so no time will be lost in the class room, and she will be contented to stay in Birch Saturday and Sunday. With your answer she will be more quiet—I hope that your letter will be satisfactory.

The last letter you wrote about the government school had a very good effect on the Indians, and I thank you very much for it. A kind cooperation between the Department and the missionary, had always good results for the welfare of the Indians and the teachers.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I am in receipt of Departmental Letter No. I9-I3/I of the 9th instant with regard to certain complaints against Miss Mary Clarke, teacher at the Birch Island Indian Day School, and in reply I have the honour to report that after taking this matter up with the Chief of Whitefish River Band he advised me that it was through a few agitators in the Band that he was forced to take this matter up with the Department.

In conversing this matter with some of the parents, the McGregors who have always been dissatisfied with the services of previous teachers in this school, I found that they had some minor complaints against Miss Clarke, such as chastising some of the pupils for lingering along the road in the mornings which caused them to be late for school, and chastising them for not taking an interest in their studies in the classroom, which she has a perfect right to do. It would appear that a few of the members of this Band would like to have control over both the teacher and the school.

It is true that on some occasions Miss Clarke closes the school before 4 p.m. in order to get the train which is due at 4 p.m., as she has to get out at week ends in order to procure her supply of provisions, but as a rule she is always back in time to open school at 9 a.m., Monday morning.

Miss Clarke is a capable teacher and has always given her services to the best interest in the classroom, and under no consideration would I recommend any change in teachers in this school during the academic year.

I re-enclosure.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have your memorandum of the 5th instant, enclosing letter from Mr. Thos Farquhar, M.P., recommending Miss Teresa Lapointe as teacher at the Birch Island Indian Day School.

The Department was informed some time ago that the present teacher at this school intends to be married, and will, therefore, be giving up duties at the end of June. However, we have no definite information on this point at the present time, but expect to know shortly, and will then advise you.

With reference to the application of Miss Teresa Lapointe, I would point out that in her letter she states that she has only junior matriculation standing, although she is at present attending high school in order to obtain her senior matriculation. She has not yet attended normal school. Under these circumstances, she is not a qualified teacher.

The Department has always employed a qualified teacher at the Birch Island School, and, as a matter of fact, practically all teachers of Indian day schools in Canada at the present time are fully qualified.

In view of the large number of qualified teachers who are now available, I feel it would not be in the best interests of the education of the Indian children at this point to engage an unqualified teacher. I feel you will agree with me in this regard, and I, therefore, enclose letter to Mr. Farquhar along these lines.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Miss Riepert:

Mrs. H. Hertzberg, Commissioner of Girl Guides for the province of Ontario, interviewed me a few weeks ago and appeared at that time to be particularly interested in a group of Girl Guides that had been organized at the Birch Island Indian Day School, Whitefish Falls, Ontario.

It appeared to me, from what Mrs. Hertzberg said, that one of her field officials had expressed the view that this was one of the best Girl Guide groups in the province of Ontario. I promised Mrs. Hertzberg at that time that I would communicate with the teacher in charge of the school, Miss Eva L. Fortin, and receive from her a brief history of the Girl Guide organization at her school. Miss Fortin, in a letter to me dated March 14, 1942, states:

"I have been working with this group of Girl Guides ever since I began teaching here, 8 years ago. I am quite satisfied with the results of the Guide movement in this village. The girls have entered several contests and always with good results. I feel sure the school work has been promoted a great deal by the work of the Guides.

"As soon as the little girls of the village attain the age of reason I invite them to come to Brownie meetings. These meetings are conducted by one of my Guides, whom I have trained to assume the responsibility of training the younger set to become Guides. This helps the little ones very much when they reach school age. When the Brownies have learned the Guide laws and grasp their significance, I enroll them in the Guide Company. From then on we follow very closely the Rules and Organization of the Girl Guides."

Miss E. A. Riepert,
General Secretary,
The Girl Guides Association,
22 College Street,
Toronto 2, Ont.
It would appear that Miss Fortin has been outstandingly successful in the organization of this group of girls, and I feel sure you will be interested to learn that the Girl Guide movement can render very useful service in the cause of Indian education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Appointment of teachers, Birch Island and Sagamook Indian Day Schools.

In response to the suggestion contained in Mr. Pratt's memorandum of September 16, I am sending forward herewith a letter addressed to Thomas Farquhar, Esq., M.P., Mindemoya, Ont. This letter explains somewhat fully and in detail the steps that have been taken to secure teachers for the above-noted schools.

When the vacancy occurred at Birch Island the matter was referred to your office. We did not feel that the school was one that would appeal to Miss MacNulty. In addition to this consideration, we had, at that date, under consideration the advisability of offering her the Dokis School. Mr. Marleau, who visited the Department about that time, was of the opinion that, in view of the experiences at Dokis last year with a young teacher, a more experienced teacher and one of mature years should be appointed to the Dokis vacancy. The correspondence on file suggests that a great deal of patience has been exercised by the Departmental officials in dealing with Miss MacNulty from time to time. She appears to have reached an age when she resents interference on the part of either the Indian Agent or the Department and is constantly having letters written on her behalf by missionaries and other citizens. When she left the Mississauga School, she did not turn over the keys to the Agent, nor did she leave her address, and this action on her part has led to a great deal of unnecessary correspondence. Were it not for the scarcity of teachers existing at the moment, I am disposed to think that it would be of

I acknowledge receipt of departmental letter dated December 15, file No.19-13-1, in regard to Miss Carmel Cahill resigning her position as teacher of Birch Island School.

I have been over to see Miss Cahill, and find that she has definitely decided to resign, and from information I could gather, the chief reason is that Miss Cahill is not strong enough to carry on here.

I was always of the impression this was a warm school as the fuel consumption appeared to be light, and there were formerly no complaints in this respect, but Miss Cahill complains the living quarters become very cold over night, which is due greatly to the fact the pipes from stoves in both kitchen and living room enter the chimney downstairs.

Miss Cahill did ask for a furnace this fall, which I expected there was no use asking for, since it had never been included in the estimates, furthermore the building is not laid out very well for a furnace.

There are nearly forty pupils at Birch Island School, with some in each grade from one to eight. This no doubt makes it quite a heavy task, and I am afraid Miss Cahill would have a break down, if she were compelled to carry on here any longer, so I would recommend her resignation be accepted.

I believe we might get either Mrs. Lawrence Peltier of Kaboni P. O., or Mrs. Henry Fox of Wikwemikong to finish out this term, if the Department have no one else in view.

Mrs. Fox was engaged, I believe, as teacher in Sturgeon Bay, but I understand owing to her mother's sickness she will leave for school nearer home.

I believe we should indicate direct with Miss Cahill that you expect she will leave if you wish me to make any arrangement above as her successor.

I like Birch Island and eventually will get to like it better.

It seems that Grades VII and VIII get all the attention in past years while the junior grades were more or less given work (written) just to keep them busy. They cannot apply themselves to any subject. Reading, spelling and literature are poor while Mathematics are far from personal.

I trust that you will understand the matter. I will do everything possible to make a successful year but I will be unable to accomplish as much as I did in other Indian schools owing to
I would appreciate a word of advice in the matter as I certainly do not wish to shrink my duty in any way.

I gave Mr. Johnston a list of requirements for the teacher's quarters but since then there are a few other articles that are needed too.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I am writing to inform you, Mr Phelan, that I am thinking of discontinuing teaching. This on the urgent advice of my doctor. Dear Mr. Phelan:

I think this is my first correspondence with you, although I have been 7/2 years at Little Current, and attending to Birch Island.

The purpose of this letter is to acquaint you with conditions at Birch Island. I think you know that the teacher there (Mary Morris) has been ordered by her doctor to go away for a rest. She will leave at Easter. In any event she seems worried that you may think that she has been somewhat of a failure. Why she should think this, I do not know. Since she came to Birch Island in Sept. I have seen more progress and improvement than in the six previous years. Further, I would say that she is one of the best teachers on the Indian list. The teachers there during the last few years have not been the best. She is laboring with children who are 2, and 3, and 4 years in one grade. She is dealing with a band that is dominated by the mentality of a slick (McGregors) who seem to think that they are better than the "whites"; better than the teacher; better than the Indian Department. She has gone to all manners to teach them order, respect and co-operation. She has fought with poor attendance (I realize that her attendance before Christmas was the best in the country), lack of interest, and co-operation from the parents; resentment of correction, pitiful lack of facilities, and many others. She has to go half a mile for all water. There is no local post office. There is one train a day. The people have not all realized that she has done her very best to make their children better. But she has. The nicest Christmas concert I have seen for a long time was at Birch Island, last Christmas. She has taught them singing, dancing, good manners, respect for authority, punctuality, and many other virtues. In short: Miss Morris has done a wonderful job. I sincerely hope that you will not get the impression that she has fallen down in any way. She hasn't. At present it is doubtful whether she will teach again. If she does it will most probably be at an Indian school, and I would like you to know that as far as I am concerned she is first class—one of the finest teachers in the north country. I know for sure that any trouble she has had at Birch Island is owing to the traditional Indian mentality—their natural resentment of the Whites, their resentment of correction, their failure to co-operate, their peculiar slowness to improve, and their funny tendency to pull the white man down to their own low level.

I would very much appreciate reply—at your convenience.

Wishing you the best luck in your difficult position,

I am yours most sincerely in Christ,

Rev. M. G. Kelly.
P.S. & gather that the B.C. Indians are angling for an Indian teacher to replace Miss Morris. In my opinion, Mr. Phelan, this would be a grave mistake. They would gloat over it, and the children would revert to carelessness & neglect of study.

For your information—
Robt Macdonald, Athabasca River, has been consulted by Miss Morris, and expresses a desire to take over school for remaining months of this semester—in case you have difficulty in finding replacement. He has certificate for Sr. Matriculation at present; this boy contemplates going to the seminary.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

BIRCH ISLAND INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

TEACHER

Miss McGregor had just reported for duty on the day of my visit, May 10. She is an Indian girl with no teaching experience and I spent most of my visit in assisting her with the planning of her classroom work. There are 25 children in Grades 1 to 7 and Miss McGregor will have her hands full in keeping them occupied.

SCHOOL and TEACHERAGE

This school is about 20 years old but is still in very good condition. The classroom is bright and is heated from a stove. It is well located, with a nice playground, and is on the highway to Little Current from Espanola. It is close to the Birch Island station on the C. P. R. line.

The teacher's quarters are good, with two bedrooms upstairs, living room and kitchen downstairs. The quarters are stove-heated but there is a basement which could be used for a furnace.

..... General
BIRCH ISLAND INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

GENERAL

This could be a very good school as the children are bright and responsive. They speak English much better than elsewhere on the Island. Because of its accessible location, we should be able to interest a teacher in this position.

Water is from a pump in the kitchen and although no hydro is available, it will eventually come along the highway.

My recommendations for this school are:

1. The placing of a new roof.
2. The building of a new woodshed.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education

Sir:

The Department is informed by Rev. E. A. Papineau, S. J., that it is the intention of Miss Irene Malone, teacher of the Birch Island Indian Day School, to give up duties at the end of the present month. The undersigned begs to report that the Whitefish River Band of Indians of the Manitowaning Agency, in the Province of Ontario, has passed a resolution asking that an expenditure of $4,000.00 be authorized from their capital funds for the purpose of erecting an Indian day school at Birch Island, which is situated within their reserve, to be conducted under the joint auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and the Department of Indian Affairs.

As this proposal is considered to be in the interests of these Indians and as there are a sufficient number of children to warrant the establishment of the school, the undersigned has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for an expenditure of the said sum of $4,000.00 from the capital funds of the said band, which now amount to $51,447.45, for the above mentioned purpose, pursuant to the provisions of Section 89 of the Indian Act.

Sir:

Referring to Official Letter No. 19-13-5 of February last, referring to the question of erecting a school building at Birch Island in the Whitefish River Reserve, I have the honour to report to the effect that I have experienced some difficulty to secure the services of a competent carpenter, who would act as foreman, but finally Mr. Thomas Smith, of Little Currant, has offered to look after the work and has asked a wage of $50.00 per week, which would appear to me to be rather high. He has been recommended by several contractors as a responsible carpenter and a fast worker.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of the list of materials necessary and estimate of cost, which has been prepared by Mr. Smith, but I am of the opinion that there will be a great deal more required before the building is complete.

It is the purpose of the Department to reduce the length of the class room to 36 feet, in place of 31'3" as shown on the plan, but I would recommend that it be erected of the original length 31'3" as the attendance of pupils is on the increase.

I might say again for the information of the Department that I believe that it would be more satisfactory to have this building erected by contract as the Whitefish River Reserve is over thirty miles from this office which will make it rather difficult and costly for me to supervise.

Mr. Smith has lead me to believe that he will erect a suitable building at a very reasonable price by contract.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
July 10, 1926.

Sir,

Reference your letter of the 2nd ultimo regarding the erection of a school at Birch Island. I note your remarks with reference to erecting this building by contract, and would say that if the building is built under contract, it will delay operations until late in the season, in order to give time to invite tenders, etc. I believe it would, therefore, be more satisfactory to build by day labour, and give as much employment as possible to the Indians. You state that in your opinion there will be a great deal more materials required than shown on the list prepared by Mr. Smith. I would ask you to please let me know what the cost of the building complete will be including labour, also it might be advisable to have Mr. Smith give you a price for all of the labour required for the building, the materials to be supplied by the Department.

In the interior finishing of the building the ceiling should be finished with a metal ceiling and the walls sheeted with fibre board or v-joint as plastering does not prove satisfactory in this type of building.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aust. Deputy and Secretary.

H. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.
