Sir:

In reply to Special Letter No. 19-13-5 of the 10th instant, I have the honour to report that I had an interview with Mr. Smith in regard to the cost of labour in erecting the proposed school at Birch Island and he advised me that he could not undertake to complete the building for anything less than $2100, and the Department to supply the material.

At Mr. Smith's estimate on the price of the material required the total cost of the building would be $4366. If the Department supplies the material the cost of the same will come higher than $2266 as I know very well before the building is complete there will be different articles required which are not included in Mr. Smith's list.

I might say that it would appear to me that the Bugwah School in this agency was built from the same plan as the Department submitted for the Birch Island School, and Mr. Strain erected the Bugwah School including woodshed, two toilets and storm windows for the school building complete for $4900. On Mr. Smith's estimate I believe that this building alone will cost as much as was paid for the building of the Bugwah School, including the toilets, woodshed and storm windows.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, informing the Department that the new school building at Birch Island is nearly completed and will soon be ready for occupancy, and requesting that classroom furnishings be supplied.

In reply I beg to say that we are asking for quotations, here, for the supplying of the number of desks, teacher's desk and chairs required, and you will be informed later as to when the order is placed. We will also place an order here for the quantity of blackboard asked for, and this will be forwarded to Birch Island, Algoma Eastern Railway, Via Sudbury.

You may purchase the 5 window shades required, also a large box stove of a type considered by you to be satisfactory to heat this building. You may also purchase the quantity of stove pipe required. If possible, you should obtain competitive prices and purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

It is hoped that you will be able to have the building entirely completed at an early date, and the outbuildings painted if the weather permits.

Sir:

Ottawa, December 15, 1926.

Sir:

A communication has been received from the teacher of the Birch Island Indian Day School in which she states that certain of the furnishings for the teacher's residence and school have not yet been supplied. In this connection I would refer you to our letter of the 3rd instant, in which you were authorized to purchase a chemical closet, a suitable table and chairs, and an alarm clock, as well as a bureau and kitchen table, and a cupboard for the classroom. We hope that you will have all of these supplies delivered at an early date.

The teacher states that she also requires a number of curtain rods and shelving in the basement on which to store her supplies. You may purchase the curtain rods required and also arrange to have shelving put up in the basement. The Department hopes that you will have all this work completed and the supplies furnished before the school reopens after the coming Christmas holidays.

We are today placing an order with the Geo. M. Hendry Co., Ltd., Toronto, to ship, freight charges prepaid, to Birch Island, one school bell, 22" in diameter, complete, except for the bell rope. The weight of this bell, with mounting, is 175 pounds, and the price F.O.B. Toronto is $30. We are requesting the above firm to forward their account, in duplicate, to you, and, upon receipt of the bell, you should certify the account and send it to the Department for payment. When this bell arrives, you should arrange to have it set up in the belfry, the necessary rope provided, and the bell placed in a serviceable condition.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a voucher in favour of Mr. Norman Tretter, of Little Current, amounting to $102.20 for extra material, and payment of freight charges on the same, furnished for the Birch Island School building.

When this building was under construction, Mr. Smith, the foreman, found that he was short of different kinds of material, and in order to not delay the work and add expense, as the labour was costing approximately $300 a week, he was authorized to order the necessary material required without delay and keep the work under way.

On account of the building being erected on the side of a small grade extra steps, handrail, pests, etc., had to be procured in order to make a proper structure to the class-room door, and extra material for the construction of two closets had to be purchased, which were not considered in the first estimate of the cost of material required.

Much difficulty has been experienced in securing receipted vouchers showing that the freight on this material was prepaid.

Ottawa, May 4th, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of levelling and fencing the school grounds around the Birch Island Indian Day School.

Relative to the levelling of the grounds, I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work done. The earth and rock taken from the cellar of the building should be placed where required in the school yard and levelled. The whole yard may be plowed, the stones removed and all holes filled in. We note that you estimate the cost of having this work carried out to be approximately $100, and this amount should not, if possible, be exceeded.

Relative to fencing the grounds, I beg to say it is considered that a suitable fence, with 2 gates, including the cost of the wire, posts, staples, etc., should be erected for less than your estimate of $150. However, as the Department is anxious to complete all work in connection with this school, you may make the necessary arrangements to have the fence enclosing the school grounds erected. You should arrange for the purchase of all posts required, and for the wire, staples, etc. Please keep the cost down to the lowest possible point. It is thought that fencing material of the Page wire type would be the most satisfactory for the purpose.

When the above work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure for the levelling of the grounds and for the fencing separately.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

In reply to Departmental Letter No. 19-13-5 of June 29th last, regarding a report received from Miss Douglas relative to the fencing of Birch Island School, and in reply I have the honour to report that the fence around this school has been erected and all completed. Approximately one acre has been enclosed and a portion of this acre has been levelled.

Since the work of levelling this ground has commenced it was found that the surface is very rough and costly to level. Only the portion of the site on the north and west sides of the school has been ploughed, stoned and levelled, which cost around $100. If the site is enlarged to the amount of two acres and this levelled the cost will be high, as a large quantity of rock will have to be removed.

An effort has been made to have this work carried out to the best advantage in the most economical manner, and the amount of ground enclosed with this school is equal to that of any other school in this agency.

I would not recommend that any more ground be enclosed at the present time.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Birch Island Indian Day School, states that 5 storm windows are required for the teacher's living quarters. I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of supplying the storm windows of the size required.

The Inspector also states that the "round sheet steel metal pipe stove" is dangerous and unsuitable and should be replaced by a small iron box stove, and that this box stove will be more reliable in every way and suitable for keeping a fire in all night, and would cost approximately $10 at Eaton's. Please state whether you would recommend that the change in stoves as suggested by the Inspector be carried out.

The Inspector further states that the cement cistern in the cellar has no cover and that consequently dirt of all kinds is floating in the water. Besides being open on top, the moisture causes the cellar to be useless. He recommends that the cistern be covered tightly and a trap door arranged in order that it can be cleaned out from time to time. I have, therefore, to request that you will have this cistern thoroughly cleaned and a cover placed over same, with a trap door or other arrangement in order to be able to clean the cistern when required. This matter should receive your early attention.

I have also to request that you will state the cost of erecting a suitable woodshed of an inexpensive type for the storage of fuel.

The Inspector has also recommended that 4 front desks be supplied to complete seating arrangements. Please furnish full shipping directions, when an order will be placed with the Globe Furniture Co., Ltd., to supply same.

The above matters should receive your early attention, and full information should be furnished the Department.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 19-13-5 of the 10th instant, with regard to the report of Mr. Inspector Bennett on his recent inspection of Birch Island School, and in reply I have the honour to report that with regard to storm windows for the teacher's living quarters these were ordered by authority of Departmental Letter No. 19-13-8 of July the 7th last, and will be installed before the cold weather sets in.

With regard to the stove, I beg to report to the Department that during the winter past a new quick heater was installed in the teacher's living quarters, which should satisfy almost any teacher, but Miss Douglas has been continually complaining about this stove and will not be satisfied until a change is made; therefore, I would recommend that it be replaced by a suitable box stove, and it may be that I can make a sale of the one in use at present. The stove recommended by the Inspector for sale by T.Eaton Company is not suitable as the firebox is too short. At the present time the wood has to be cut in two different lengths, and if the one he recommends be installed the wood will have to be cut in three lengths.

If possible a cover will be placed on the cistern, but it will be somewhat difficult as the walls of the cistern has been built up close to the bottom of the kitchen floor and there has been very little space left for a cover and a trap door. All the water in the cistern is caught from the roof of the building and dirt that collects in the cistern is from the roof and not from the cellar.

An estimate on the cost of erecting a suitable woodshed will be submitted in the near future.

The number and description of desks required were requisitioned for on the 10th instant, these should be shipped by C.P.Railway to Sudbury, thence A.E.Railway to Birch Island Station.

Secretary School Board,
Birch Island, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report having visited your school on May 7th and took a sample of water from your school well to be tested at the Soo Laboratory. The report on the analysis, a copy of which I am enclosing, shows that the water is 'unsatisfactory' and unfit for drinking purposes unless it is boiled or chlorinated.

This well is unprotected from surface drains which naturally contaminate the water. It should be properly stoned up or cemented with a good tight cement covering and banked around to prevent contamination from surface water. Should this be done the water would improve in quality and be satisfactory and safe for drinking purposes.

In the meantime and until this well has been properly protected a good water supply could be secured from a spring between the school and the road camp.

I will be making a trip down the Algoma Eastern within a month or six weeks and hope to find that improvements have been made to the well.

Yours sincerely,

H.B. McCauley
Provincial Sanitary Inspector.
Ottawa, June 1st, 1929.

Sir:

The Provincial Sanitary Inspector, who recently visited the Birch Island Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the water supply. He states that he had a sample of the water analyzed and that it is unfit for drinking purposes unless boiled or chlorinated. He also states that the well is unprotected from surface drains which naturally contaminate the water, and recommends that it be properly stoned up or cemented with a good tight cement covering and banked around to prevent contamination from surface water. Should this be done, the water would improve in quality and be satisfactory and safe for drinking purposes.

I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange to have this well properly stoned up or cemented, and a tight cement covering placed over the well. This matter should receive your early attention. Please keep all costs as low as possible, and, when the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

The cellar of my school is so cold that all food stuffs freeze and the ice is formed to a thickness of ten inches on the surface.

There is already a stove in the cellar but no stove-pipes. It would cost $3.50 to rig up the stove and enable me to make an occasional fire that would thin the ice and protect my provisions. Will you kindly authorize me to secure these stove-pipes from the nearest store?

I am writing direct to you so as to avoid delay since I think this needs immediate attention. This cellar being concrete it is apt to crack which would render it useless.

I am hoping to receive a favorable reply and thanking you for past favours.

I remain

Yours truly,

Mary Stein
Ottawa, February 17, 1930.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, and in reply have to inform you that Mr. Agent Lewis is being instructed to arrange for the purchase and installation of the quantity of stove pipe required by you for a stove in the cellar of the Birch Island Indian Day School. It is noted that you require this stove for the purpose of heating the cellar in order to prevent your food supplies from being frozen and also to protect the cistern from being broken by freezing. Mr. Lewis has been requested to supply this stove pipe and have it installed at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Mary Wrinn,
Teacher, Birch Island Indian Day School,
Ponct, Ont.
Ottawa, February 17, 1930.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Miss Mary Wrinn, teacher of the Birch Island Indian Day School, requesting that stove pipe be supplied for the use of the stove in the cellar of the school. She states that the cellar is so cold that all food stuff freezes and that there is danger of the cistern becoming broken by freezing. She states that if stove pipe to the approximate cost of $3.50 were supplied she would be able to make an occasional fire in the stove, which would protect the provisions and the cistern.

I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange as soon as possible to supply the quantity of stove pipe required and have same installed, and you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. We are informing Miss Wrinn that you have been authorized to supply and install the stove pipe required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning,
Ont.

Dear Sir,

On my visit to the department at Owen Sound I suggested that the interior walls of the school be painted. This you agreed to and asked me if I could name an Indian who would be capable of doing this work during the Easter holidays. After much enquiry I find there is no one on the Reserve who has any experience in painting.

However there are some professional painters doing some work on a tourist's cottage here and I inquired from them if they could do the painting in the school. They are willing to do the work and at a reasonable price also. I know them to be honest and trustworthy men so that we could be sure of a good job.

I think it would be very advisable to engage these men as I don't know...
of an Indian with whom I could trust the key.

I explained to you at Tomas the condition in which I found the school last September which was due to the Indians having the full run of the school during the summer holiday. They even told me that they had a skeleton key which would fit any door in the school. This difficulty I overcome by putting a Yale lock on at my own expense.

Hoping to receive a reply at the earliest date possible I beg to remain

Yours truly,

Mary Heim
Indian Office, Manitowaning,
March 25th, 1930.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of Departmental Letter No. I9-I3-5 of March 13th instant, enclosing there-with a communication from Miss Mary Wrinn concerning the question of painting the interior of the Birch Island School, and in reply I have the honour to report that I would not advise painting the interior of this building at this time of the year as the weather is too cold in this district to have it carried out successfully, and besides the exterior of this building will have to be repainted during the incoming summer when it is warm and at than time both jobs can be carried out at the same time, and can be done more cheaply in the summer months than now.

The interior of this building is finished with cedar lumber and has never been painted. It was thought that if this finish is oiled and then given two coats of varnish it would be much better that putting paint on cedar lumber.

I might say also, that there is ample Indian labour available during the summer months to have such work as this carried out.

I am re-enclosing herewith Miss Wrinn's letter, as requested.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant relative to the request of the teacher of the Birch Island Indian Day School that the interior of the school be painted. In this connection, it is noted that you recommend that the exterior of the building be also painted and that all this work be carried out during the summer months. In the meantime, you might furnish an estimate of the cost of the painting required to the exterior of the building and also the interior. It is noted that you consider the interior of the building, which is finish in cedar, be oiled and given two coats of varnish instead of being painted.

You should furnish full information as to the work that should be done together will your estimate of the cost and if funds can be provided, authority would be granted in due time to have the work carried out during the coming summer holidays.

The teacher is being informed that any painting required to the school building, will have to stand over until the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Office, Manitowaning,
April 30th, 1930.

Sir:—

Referring to Departmental Letter No. IOO5-IO of the 31st of March last, and previous correspondence concerning the question of having the Birch Island School painted, I have the honour to report that in order to give the exterior portion of this building two coats of pure whitelead and linseed oil it will cost approximately $150. As there is more surface to cover in the interior painting it will cost somewhere around $200, or a total of $350 to have both exterior and interior painted.

It was first thought that the interior should be finished with linseed oil and varnish, but as the class room and teacher's living quarters is a little on the dark side it has been decided that if painted in a bright colour would be more suitable.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 5th, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, relative to the painting required to the exterior and interior of the Birch Island Indian Day School, and giving an estimate of the cost.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of having this work done during the period the school is closed for the coming summer holidays, in order that there will be no interference with the classroom activity. In the meantime, however, you should inform the Department how you would recommend that the work be carried out. It is considered that it would be advisable to have the work done under the charge of a competent foreman, employing Indian labour as far as possible, you to make the purchase of all paint, oils, varnish and other materials required, and have proper time sheets kept of the labour employed. However, before issuing definite instructions, you should furnish your recommendation as to how you would advise that this work be carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, relative to the painting of the Birch Island Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the recommendation made by you for the carrying out of this work is approved. You should arrange for the purchase of a good grade of paint, oils, etc. The labour in doing the work may be under the charge of Mr. John King. Time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed. You should see that the work is satisfactorily performed. The exterior portion of the building should be given two coats of paint of the colours considered suitable by yourself. The interior of the classroom and teacher's living quarters should receive one coat. The Department will expect you to see that a satisfactory job is carried out in the painting of this building, and the work should be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

You should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the paint, oils, etc., also time sheets, in duplicate, signed by the individual labourers and certified by yourself, when payment will be made.

Manitowaning, July 2nd, 1931.

Sir:-

I have the honour to report that I am in receipt of a communication from Mr. R.B. McCauley, Provincial Sanitary Inspector, Scegont, to the effect that he has been instructed by the Department of Health at Toronto to make a sanitary survey of all schools in unorganized territory in his district, and that on June the 11th he make an inspection of the Birch Island Separate School, and he reports as follows:-

In regard to ventilation, he would suggest that I would secure glass frames to be used as a baffle against the direct draft when the lower sash is open. These frames are attached to the inside window sill and set at an oblique angle deflecting the draft over the heads of the children.

He also suggests that a small covered water tank be secured with a tap at the bottom to be used in place of the open pail, and that sanitary drinking cups be provided. This would be the means of lessening the possibility of spreading communicable disease, and he suggests that an effort be made to secure water on the school property, and that it will be necessary for him to make a return visit to this school after the summer holidays and would like to see that the necessary improvements have been attended to.

I might say for the information of the Department that some of the Inspector's suggestions, if carried out, will be costly to the Department, such as having a well drilled on the property. At present the supply of water is secured from a well across the road from the school.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, July 11, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, relative to a communication which you received from the Provincial Sanitary Inspector, Sault Ste. Marie, in which he makes certain recommendations regarding the Birch Island Indian Day School.

With reference to the providing of glass frames to prevent direct draughts from the windows when the lower sash is open, I have to say that the Department is not prepared to authorize supplying this equipment.

Relative to the providing of a well, it is noted that a supply of water can be obtained from a well across the road from the school, and the Department is not prepared to undertake the expenditure required in drilling a well near the school.

Regarding the suggestion that a small covered water cooler, with tap at the bottom, be provided, I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase and delivery at the school of this cooler after the summer holidays. It is considered that a cooler of approximately 5 or 6 gallon capacity, with tap, would be satisfactory. You may also arrange for the purchase and delivery of individual enamel mugs for the pupils' use. After you have made the above purchases, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Should the Sanitary Inspector, on his return visit, communicate with you further regarding the requirements at this school, you should forward his letter to the Department for the necessary action.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Provincial Sanitary Inspector reporting on his recent visit to the Birch Island Indian Day School.

Regarding the supplying of individual drinking cups, I have to say that this Department does not supply sanitary paper drinking cups. We usually supply granite-ware drinking cups, which has been done in the case of this school.

Regarding the outside toilets, it is noted the Inspector recommends that they be banked up with earth around the outside, as they are from eight to ten inches above the ground and sitting on blocks. I have to request that you will arrange to have these closets banked this Fall, as recommended by the Inspector. It should not cost very much to have this work done. Please give this matter your prompt attention. You can, no doubt, obtain the services of a competent Indian to bank the toilets. After the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

I might add that if the boxes in the toilets require to be cleaned out you should also have this work done.

ISSUED BY SANITARY INSPECTION BRANCH
DIVISION OF INDUSTRIAL HYGIENE.
ONTARIO DEPT. OF HEALTH.

JULY 1932
SPECIFICATIONS FOR INSTALLATION OF SCHOOL VENTILATION SYSTEM.

AIR INLET:
Air inlet duct to be run from a point 2'6" from the ground level in through outside wall with inlet opening to room directly under middle of stove. Damper to be installed as shown in plan at convenient point on inside wall. A small mesh screen to be placed on inside opening and outside inlet.

ROOF LOUVRE VENTILATOR:
Roof ventilator to be connected to a 12" duct run from ceiling level. This roof ventilator to be installed at a point in roof farthest away from stove site. A damper regulated by four pulleys and two pull ropes to be installed in ceiling.

STOVE:
Stove to have movable jacket, this to be constructed of galvanized iron supported on iron or wooden supports, the inside to be covered with sheet asbestos; a space of 6" to be left between the bottom of jacket and floor.

Air inlet duct, roof duct and ventilator to be constructed of wood.

OPERATION OF VENTILATION SYSTEM.
Wall and roof dampers to be shut during cold weather when school classes are over each day and re-opened when the necessary temperature of from 65°F. to 70°F. has been reached next day when school re-opens and the heating system is functioning.

A thermometer placed mid-way between stove and outside walls at a height of about 5' should be in each school room.
Manitowaning, December 31st, 1932.

Sir:

Re: Birch Island Indian Day School.

I have the honour to report that R. B. McCauley, Provincial Sanitary Inspector, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., having made an inspection at the above school, and has advised me that the following improvements will have to be made in order that this school may comply with the Regulations:

In securing new blinds it will be found that cream will be more satisfactory than green blinds, which the class room is equipped with at present. The yellow shed more mellow light.

A new standard system of ventilation is recommended for rural schools and a blue print is being issued by the Department of Health. I am enclosing a copy of this and also instructions in regard to installation and operation furnished by the Inspector. He states that these are sent to all schools in Ontario, and he would be pleased if the Department could have this system installed at their earliest convenience. He advises that little expense is involved in the installation and that it will be found a great improvement in the ventilation.

With regard to the above I would advise the Department that all the windows in the classroom are equipped with green shades which are in fairly good condition, and the classroom system of ventilation is from lowering the upper portion of the windows which has proved quite satisfactory.

Manitowaning, October 31st, 1933.

Sir:-

I have the honour to enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for use at the Birch Island Indian Day School.

When at Birch Island on the evening of the 30th instant, making distribution of fall interest to the Indians of Whitefish River Band I paid the school a visit and found that the teacher is in need of all the articles asked for on this requisition.

During September last, one dozen drinking cups were supplied, but as there is an enrolment of twenty six pupils and for sanitary precautions the teacher would like to have another dozen in order that they would have individual drinking cups.

The hooks in the cloak rooms should be renewed with new ones as the hooks which have been in use were of cheap grade and are of no further use.

Past Bane should be supplied in order to prevent so much dust when sweeping the classroom floor.

The oilcloth in use on the kitchen table is worn out and should be renewed with a sufficient amount to recover the table.

A bread box should be supplied as the teacher has to order enough bread to last a week from Little Current, or some outside point where there is a bakery, and should have a box for storing her supply.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I enclose herewith a requisition by Miss Mary Clarke for articles for use at the Birch Island Indian School.

The tooth brushes which have been in use by the pupils are worn out, and a fresh supply is required.

The doors and windows in the teacher's residence have shrunken. These cracks let a lot of cold in. It was thought by putting some weather stripping over these openings it would assist in keeping the cold out to some extent.

The sheets that were supplied in the fall of 1934 are almost worn out, and should be replaced by a new pair, also two pillow cases should be supplied.

Five new electric light bulbs should be supplied for use in the classroom and all the bulbs which have been in use during the past are of no further use.

All the articles asked for on this requisition should be supplied as they are required by the teacher in the classroom and her living quarters.

Manitowaning, November 28th, 1935.

Sir:

Miss Mary Clarke, teacher at the Birch Island Indian School, has made enquiry as to whether the Department allow any grant for a Christmas Concert. She states that if she could get about five dollars to help pay for crepe paper and costumes etc she would be very pleased as she is putting a concert on to get funds for the Girl Guides.

Yesterday I visited Birch Island School and had an interview with Miss Clarke concerning this matter. She advised me that as there is very little entertainment for the children at Birch Island during Christmas season she tries to have a concert in the classroom each year for the pupils attending school, but finds it difficult to secure material for decoration, costumes, etc, and the parents cannot provide the same.

In order that Miss Clarke may make a success of the proposed Entertainment I would most respectfully recommend that the Department allow her a small grant, not exceeding $5.00, to enable her to provide material for costumes etc.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Manitowaning, October 13th, 1936.

Sir:

I enclose herewith a requisition by Miss Eva Fortin for supplies for use at the Birch Island Indian School.

As the supply of water for the school is carried some distance by the pupils two extra pails is required for this purpose, and five yards of table oilcloth is asked for to cover the table in the classroom on which the pupils take their hot drink during the winter months.

There is not any wash board for laundry purpose, and not sufficient table knives and forks, cups and saucers or table spoons, and the curtains on the windows in the classroom are worn out.

I would recommend that all these articles asked for be supplied:

- 2 water pails
- 5 yards of oilcloth
- 1 wash board
- 6 knives and forks
- 6 cups and saucers
- 6 dessert spoons
- 10 yards curtain material

The approx. cost of the above will amount to $10.25.

With regard to the supply of cocoa, sugar and milk asked for classroom lunch, I would recommend that the Department allow an expenditure of $4.00 per month from the 1st of December 1936 to March 31st 1937 for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I herewith wish to make an appeal to have a well dug near the school house, before the cold season.

As it stands now, we have to carry drinking water from the Bay, a distance of at least one quarter of a mile, and up a very steep hill. This is indeed a very difficult task on cold winter days.

Thanking you for any consideration on the matter,

I am,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Eva Fortin,

August 1st, 1939

Sir:-

With reference to your letter to the former Indian Agent, R. J. Lewis, dated Sept. 25, 1938 No. 19-13-5 in regard to a request from Miss Eva Fortin, to have a well dug at the Birch Island Indian Day School, I wish to report, upon investigation, I find there is no possibility of obtaining water near the school without drilling, but they should certainly have a well at the school; and I would judge from the surroundings, it would not be a big job to obtain water. There is outcropping of granite not a great distance away, but at the school house it appears to be all limestone, with possibly five or six feet of earth to dig, to the rock.

I have found a man at Little Current who will move his machine over and put down the well for $2.00 per foot. It would cost $35.00 to $40.00 for a pump complete with piping rods, etc., depending on the depth, and there should be a casing from the top of the ground down a short distance into the rock and cemented around to keep out surface water.

I imagine we would get water at fifty feet or less which would cost altogether in the neighbourhood of $150.00.

I would recommend this work be undertaken within the next month or two, or it would not be possible to get the machine over without shipping by rail.

I enclose herewith Miss Fortin's letter as requested.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Indian Agent C. R. Johnston, of the Manitoulin Island agency, in the Federal Constituency of Algoma East, states that a well is urgently needed at the Birch Island Indian Day School. There has never been a well at this particular school. The records indicate that the teacher has been making an attempt to secure a water supply from a small lake a considerable distance from the school.

The Agent in his communication states:

"I have found a man at Little Current who will move his machine over and put down the well for $2.00 per foot. It would cost $35.00 to $40.00 for a pump complete with piping rods, etc., and there should be a casing from the top of the ground down a short distance into the rock and cemented around to keep out surface water. I imagine we can get water at fifty feet or less, which would cost in the neighbourhood of $150.00".

It would appear from a number of reports submitted to the Department on conditions surrounding this school that there is little difficulty experienced in securing water in the district at the 50 feet level. I would recommend, therefore, subject to the approval of the Minister, that the Agent be authorized to proceed with the construction of this well. It will not be possible to move the drilling machine into this district except by rail unless the work is undertaken not later than September. A quotation was secured from Jonathan Morphet, Little Current, Ont.

Director.

Sir:

I wish to make a report on Birch Island School. The chimney is in bad shape and should be re-built down to the roof. It appears to have been poorly built or at least a poor grade of mortar used although inside where it was not exposed to the weather seems to be alright. In its present condition it is quite dangerous as there is a cement slab on top which I believe was not water proof and has admitted water causing the mortar to crumble. It should also be extended 18" higher so as to be little higher than peak of roof. It is impossible to determine the exact number of new brick required, but I would estimate it at five hundred to replace the spoiled ones, and make the 18" extension. It will also need three or four new flue tile. It is a double flue chimney.

Harper Brothers of Little Current have offered to furnish all material and labour to repair for sixty dollars, which I think is very reasonable, as they do excellent work.

The cellar drain which has been built with ordinary rock needs overhauling, as the basement floods every spring, the teacher informs me. I would recommend using tile instead of rock.

Harper Brothers have offered to furnish the sixty feet of tile necessary and have it installed by Indian labour for fifteen dollars. They could oversee this job while building the chimney, if granted.

We should also have one bunch of shingles, to repair the wood-shed roof, which is leaking badly in a few places. This will cost about $25 for material and labour.

The teacher, Miss Fontin, has offered to paint the living quarters herself over week ends, if she could have the paint furnished, which will cost about $3.00. The rooms have become quite dull and gloomy and I would recommend the paint be furnished for her.

The teacher has also asked for about $3.00 worth of dust pans for the class room.

We had to drill seventy feet at the Birch Island School, before obtaining water, but were successful in getting a plentiful supply of apparently good water. This will cost approximately sixty dollars more than I estimated, as I expected we would not have to go more than fifty feet deep.

If funds are available, I would advise having the chimney and drain attended to immediately, as from what I have heard it is difficult to get a good job.

Yours truly,
